question: Mrs. Langtry, I'm sorry.
answer: Why? What's wrong?

question: You are a valued customer, as you know.
answer: But what's wrong?

question: I can't understand a thing like this. It's something you almost never see.
answer: What is?

question: This is some of the finest filigreed platinum I've ever seen. But the stones, no. They're not diamonds, Mrs. Langtry.
answer: But they must be! They cut glass!

question: Glass will cut glass, Mrs. Langtry. Do you know where it was purchased?
answer: It was a gift. It isn't worth anything at all?

question: Why, of course it is. I can offer you -- well, five hundred dollars.
answer: All right.

question: I hope you're not too badly disappointed with us, Mrs. Langtry.
answer: It's not your fault.

question: You'll give us an opportunity to serve you again, I hope. If there's anything you think we might be interested in...
answer: I have only one thing now. Are you interested?

question: Well, I'd have to see it, of course.
answer: You are seeing it. You're looking right at it.

question: I see. You know something, Mrs. Langtry? A bracelet like that very rarely happens. A fine setting and workmanship usually mean precious stones. It always hurts me when I find they're not. I always hope -- -- I'm mistaken.
answer: Thank you. For everything you felt you could do.

question: Put it this way, now. Say I rent to a woman, well, she has to have a room with a bath. I insist on it, because otherwise she's got the hall bath tied up all the time, washing her goddamn hair and her clothes and everything she can think of. Now, your minimum for a room with bath is three hundred a month, just for a place to sleep and no cooking allowed. And just how many of these tootsies make that kind of money and have to eat in restaurants and buy clothes and --
answer: Mr. Simms.

question: Why yes, Mr. Dillon. Here's a potential new neighbor, looking at--
answer: Uh-huh. Mrs. Langtry may drop by.

question: Well, well. In a real hurry, are we?
answer: Always, for you, baby.

question: You aren't taking me for granted, are you?
answer: Taking you for granite? That isn't granite. If that fell on me, it wouldn't hurt at all.

question: Are you sure?
answer: Let's find out.

question: Roy?
answer: Mm?

question: Look at me.
answer: Oh, I am, baby, believe me.

question: Roy? It this all we have?
answer: All? It ain't bad.

question: No more than this?
answer: What are you talking abut, Myra? Marriage?

question: I didn't say that. You aren't marriage material. What's that?
answer: Ow! Hey, what are you trying to do, throw me off my game?

question: Wait'll next year. Damn that guy. Smack. Heads. Heads. Tails. Tails. How much can I bet? The fifty or the hundred? The ace is what I want? Is that okay?
answer: CU, Roy's sweat-covered face, eyelids fluttering.

question: Dark in here. Too dark. I just can't see. Let me borrow these, will you? Now, that's better.
answer: AN ANGLE across Roy toward the doorway. Roy, eyes closed, smiles in triumph, then winces in pain. Mintz partially appears, hovering beside the bed, grinning at Roy.

question: You taught me a lot. Then I invented. Let me see how you did that one. I can't. I just left home. I am in school. In your other hand.
answer: AN ANGLE across the unmoving unconscious Roy toward the doorway. The apartment door beyond the living room opens, throwing light on Roy, who doesn't react. Lilly enters, in silhouette, closes the door, crosses toward the bedroom.

question: What? He's going to be all right! Well, make it stop! You know who I work for. My son will be all right. If he isn't, I'll have you killed.
answer: Your kid's in the back here. He's crying.

question: Roy? He's always crying.
answer: The kids beat him up, because his home life is, uh, different.

question: I like you, too.
answer: Roy, your mother's here.

question: So what's your story today?
answer: They twisted my arm.

question: Only one arm?
answer: They knocked out my tooth!

question: Only one tooth?
answer: You always say that!

question: No, really, you're Roy's mother? That's impossible!
answer: Not quite. But I'm not sure who you are, Mrs... Langtry, was it?

question: I'm Roy's friend.
answer: Yes. I imagine you're lots of people's friend.

question: Oh, of course, now that I see you in the light, you're plenty old enough to be Roy's mother.
answer: Aren't we all?

question: Nice to see you. What am I doing in here?
answer: You were bleeding inside, honey. Remember that bruise you had?

question: You called the doctor, huh?
answer: Well, no, Roy. Your mother found you.

question: Oh, yeah? Thanks. How long do they say I'm in here?
answer: Roy... Your mom saved your life.

question: Yeah? Only one life?
answer: Second time I gave it to you.

question: I was kind of... inconvenient... for Lilly.
answer: Well... You're all right now, I guess. I have to get down to the track.

question: Thanks, uh, Lilly.
answer: Don't mention it.

question: I guess I owe you my life.
answer: You always did.

question: I don't see why you're still here. You look healthy to me.
answer: I just do what the doctor says, babe.

question: You're just comfortable, that's all. You don't even ask to go home. You just lie around, let your mama take care of you.
answer: Mama!

question: Who else is paying for all this? You badmouth the woman all the time, but you sure do take the payoffs she gives you.
answer: I'll pay Lilly back, don't you worry about that.

question: I don't like to come here, Roy. Every time I do, your mother comes in and makes remarks.
answer: That's just Lilly's way.

question: And you never defend me. You're afraid of her.
answer: Oh, don't be stupid.

question: You're a mama's boy, if you want the truth.
answer: Are you kid --? I hadn't even seen her in seven years!

question: What happened to your hand?
answer: Just a little accident. I went by your place, picked up your mall. Just bills, I'll take care of them.

question: I can take care of my own bills, Lilly.
answer: Whatever you say. The manager says your boss called. Really pulled the wool over everybody's eyes, huh?

question: What are you talking about? So I've got a job. So what?
answer: Stop kidding me! Four years in a town like Los Ang-gleez, and a peanut selling job is the best you can do? You expect me to believe that?

question: It's there. The boss called, you said so yourself.
answer: And that dump you live in! Those clown pictures on the walls!

question: I like those.
answer: You do not! Roy Dillon? Cornball clown pictures? Commission salesman? It's all a front, isn't it? You're on the grift, I know you are. You're working some angle, and don't tell me you're not because I wrote the book!

question: You're one to talk. Still running playback money for the mob.
answer: That's me. That's who I am. You were never cut out for the rackets, Roy, and if you --

question: How come?
answer: You aren't tough enough.

question: Not as tough as you, huh?
answer: No. And you have to be. You asked me about this. You really want to know what happened?

question: Up to you.
answer: My boss is a guy named Bobo Justus, back in Baltimore. When a long shot gets too much action, I have to put money on that horse at the track, because it's the only way to get the odds down.

question: Sure.
answer: The first day of the Delmar meet, there was a nag called Bluebell. I should have been on it. But that was the day after you came in here, so I stuck around to see how you were gonna be. That was my choice, nothing to do with you. I took a chance, and it didn't work out.

question: Bluebell came in?
answer: I sent Bobo ten grand of my own money, like it was the winnings from my bets. I hoped that would cover me. It didn't. Hi, Bobo.

question: I sent Bobo ten grand of my own money, like it was the winnings from my bets. I hoped that would cover me. It didn't. Hi, Bobo.
answer: Did I buy you that dress, you piece of shit?

question: Well, I guess so. You're the guy I work for.
answer: You work for me, huh? Then I just may flush you down the toilet. Drive me to the Durando. Bluebell. How'd you figure you were gonna get away with that?

question: I'm not getting away with anything, Bobo.
answer: You're fuckin right you're not. How much did your pals cut you in for on that nag, huh? Or did they give you the same kind of screwing you gave me?

question: I was down on that horse, Bobo. Not as much as I should have been, but there was a lot of action on those--
answer: One question. Do you want to stick to that story, or do you want to keep your teeth?

question: I want to keep my teeth.
answer: Now I'll ask you another. You think I got no contacts out here? That nag paid off at just the opening price. There wasn't hardly a flutter on the tote board from the time the odds were posted. There ain't enough action to tickle the tote, but you claim a ten grand win! You send me ten thousand dollars, like I'm some mark you can blow off!

question: Bobo, no, I --
answer: You wanna talk to me straight up?

question: My son --
answer: Your what?

question: My son was in the hospital --
answer: What the fuck are you doin with a son?

question: He left home a long time ago. He was in the hospital, up in Los Ang gleez, real sick.
answer: Motherhood.

question: I never fucked up before, Bobo.
answer: You expect me to buy this?

question: You do buy it, Bobo. I cost you, and I'm sorry.
answer: I got a lot of people work for me, Lilly. I can't have shit like this.

question: It'll never happen again. I swear.
answer: It happened once. With me, that's making a habit of it.

question: You're calling the shots.
answer: You got any kind of long coat in the car? Anything you can wear home over your clothes?

question: No.
answer: I'll loan you a raincoat. Take a walk. Get me a bath towel. You ever hear about the oranges?

question: You mean, the insurance frammis?
answer: Tell me about the oranges, Lilly. While you put those in the towel.

question: You hit a person with the oranges in the towel, they get big, awful looking bruises, but they don't really get hurt, not if you do it right. It's for working scams against insurance companies.
answer: And if you do it wrong?

question: It can louse up your insides. You can get puh, puh, puh...
answer: What's that, Lilly?

question: Permanent damage.
answer: You'll never shit right again. Bring me the towel. Go clean yourself up. The raincoat's on the bed. Almost forgot. That ten grand of yours. It's in the envelope by the door.

question: Oh, thanks, Bobo.
answer: You want a drink?

question: Gee, I better not, if it's okay. I still gotta drive back up to Los Ang-gleez.
answer: See your son, huh? Well, that's nice. A side of you I didn't know, Lilly.

question: He's a good kid. A salesman.
answer: On the square, huh? And how are you making out these days? Stealing much?

question: From you? My folks didn't raise any stupid kids.
answer: Not skimming a thing, Lilly?

question: Oh, well, you know. I just clip a buck here and a buck there. Not enough to notice.
answer: That's right. Take a little, leave a little.

question: A person that don't look out for himself is too dumb to look out for anybody else. He's a liability, right, Bobo?
answer: You're a thousand percent right!

question: Or else he's working an angle. If he doesn't steal a little, he's steeling big.
answer: You know it, Lilly.

question: You know, I like that suit, Bobo. I don't know what there is about it, but it somehow makes you look taller.
answer: Yeah? You really think so? A lot of people been telling me the same thing.

question: Well, you can tell them I said they're right. I better get going. Roy'll wonder where I am.
answer: Worries about his mother, eh? Give him a hug for me.

question: Lucky? You call that lucky?
answer: He let me live. He let me be his friend.

question: You don't put up with that! Nobody has to put up with that!
answer: You do if you're where I am. Where you want to be. How'd you get that punch in the stomach, Roy?

question: I tripped over a chair.
answer: Get off the grift, Roy.

question: Why?
answer: You don't have the stomach for it. I just give you your life. What you do with it is up to you.

question: Babe, I'm gettin out of here, and that's it. Let's take some time out this weekend, go down to LaJolla, hit the beach, have some fun. Forget all this other stuff, huh?
answer: Your difference between your folded towel and your clean towel is a trip to the laundry. When you're cleaning those bathrooms, what you do, you pick up the towel, you give it a good shake and a good look, and you say to yourself, 'Would I dry myself on this towel?' If the answer's yes, fold it. Mr. Dillon! Welcome back! You look fine, just fine.

question: Thanks, Mr. Simms, I'm feeling fine.
answer: You're well liked around here, Mr. Dillon. The entire staff will be pleased to see you're back.

question: Well, thank you. And thank them.
answer: Sickness comes to us all, Mister Dillon.

question: That's true, Mr. Simms.
answer: We never know when and we never know why. We never know how. The only blessed thing we know is, it'll be at the most inconvenient and unexpected time. Just when you've got tickets to the World Series. And that's the way the permanent waves.

question: Well, I'm back now. I just wanted you to know. Gotta rush.
answer: Happy to see you looking so good. That fellow could be a congressman. If it's wet, you don't fold it. You shake it, and hang it neatly on the rod provided.

question: Roy! Welcome back.
answer: What's going on? This is usually coffee break time.

question: Not since Kaggs showed up.
answer: Hey, yeah, I'm fine, everything's great. What's this Kaggs? Sounds like a disease.

question: Troubleshooter from the main office. Came out here right after you went into the hospital, and he ain't had a kind word for anybody yet. He chopped off half a dozen salesmen; won't wholesale to them any more.
answer: You think he'll chop me?

question: Kaggs. Home office.
answer: Roy Dillon.

question: I know that. Knew it when I saw you out there. The best salesman here, which isn't saying much. Want to talk to you, Dillon. What's up?
answer: That was a pretty backhanded compliment. If I let people get away with things like that, I wouldn't be a good salesman.

question: You're right. I apologize. But I still want to talk to you.
answer: Lead on.

question: Take a seat. When I said you being the best salesman here didn't say much, I meant for us. I know your record with Sarber and Webb, and I'd say you're a top-flight man, but you've had no incentive. No one walking on your heels. Just a lot of half asses, so the tendency's been not to stretch yourself. I'm bouncing the slobs, incidentally.
answer: So I heard.

question: Makes no difference to me if they're only on commission. If they don't make good money, they're not giving us good representation, and we can't afford to have them around. Ever supervise salesmen?
answer: Just myself.

question: That's right, you've had to supervise yourself. This place needs a sales manager. Somebody who's proved he's a salesman and can handle other salesmen. He'd have a lot of deadwood to clear out, new men to hire. What do you think?
answer: Sounds like a good Idea.

question: I don't know offhand what your best year's been, we can look it up. The idea is, we'll top it by fifteen percent.
answer: What? Me?

question: That's just the first year. If you aren't worth a lot more than that the second year, I'll kick you out. What do you say?
answer: Well, uh... No.

question: No?
answer: I can't take that job! I mean, I mean, I can't take it right away. I'm still recuperating, I just dropped in to say hello, see everybody --

question: I didn't realize. Yeah, you do look a little pale. How soon will you be ready? A week?
answer: But you need a man right now. It wouldn't be fair to you to --

question: I take care of the being-fair-to-me department. Things've gone to hell this long, they can go a little longer.
answer: Well...

question: See you in a week, Roy. I can call you Roy?
answer: Oh, sure. Fine.

question: And I'm Perk. Short for Percy, I'm afraid.
answer: Perk.

question: This really is it. Union Station.
answer: I don't see why we have to take the train.

question: Because it's comfortable.
answer: What if we want to drive somewhere while we're there?

question: We'll rent a car.
answer: Big spender.

question: You ain't seen nothin. Stretch my legs. Come along?
answer: No.

question: See you soon. Oh! Ow, I'm sorry! Oh, look, I spilled your drinks! Let me buy you a new round.
answer: You didn't like spill much at all.

question: What are those, bloody Marys? Watch this, I'll be back.
answer: Yeah, but it was you like told the sergeant your grandmother was dead.

question: Boy! You guys could've got in a lot of trouble.
answer: Nah. Old Sarge, he's slowing down.

question: I don't know. I wouldn't take a chance like that. What's that? One of you fellows drop this?
answer: Like our turn!

question: Tell you what. We'll roll for it. Low number buys. Go ahead. You roll for the four of you.
answer: That's a four!

question: Pretty woman like you shouldn't eat alone. Whadaya wanna eat alone for?
answer: Go away. Could I have some coffee, please?

question: We could have coffee together. My name's Kenny.
answer: Your pal wants you.

question: Let him find his own pretty woman.
answer: Yes.

question: I'll sit here. Move over.
answer: Oh! Are you all right? I shouldn't have hit him that hard. I guess I don't know my own strength. I thought I did. You should take better care of your friend.

question: Outta here.
answer: I'm sorry a lady can't eat in here without being bothered. That sounds nice. Pecan pie. Thank you.

question: You were right, I had to get out of that hospital. Nothing wrong with me any more.
answer: I'll sign that affidavit.

question: Great to get away, take it easy. Next week, I'll get back to work.
answer: You already went back to work.

question: What?
answer: I watched you. Working the tap on those soldier boys.

question: Working the what?
answer: Oh, come on, Roy. The tap. What you do for a living.

question: I'm a salesman.
answer: You're on the grift. Same as me.

question: Myra, I'm not following this.
answer: Roy, you're a short-con operator. And a good one, I think. Don't talk to me like I'm another square.

question: You talk the lingo. What's your pitch?
answer: The long end. Big con.

question: Nobody does that single-o.
answer: I was teamed ten years with the best in the business. Cole Langley.

question: I've heard the name.
answer: It was beautiful. And getting better all the time.

question: Is that right?
answer: It is, Roy! And now, right now, it's the perfect time, the best time since I've been in the game. All over the southwest, you've got these businessmen, they were making money when everybody was making money, they think that means they're smart. And now they're hurting. Everything they had was because of oil. They still got money, but they need more money, and that's just the kind of guy Cole and me like. When the oil money was good, they put up all these office buildings, and now they're half empty. They'll give you anything to move in; first two months free, redecoration, whatever you want. They help you set up the store! I'm the roper, I go out and find them and bring them in. Cole ran the store, and he was the best.

question: It is, Roy! And now, right now, it's the perfect time, the best time since I've been in the game. All over the southwest, you've got these businessmen, they were making money when everybody was making money, they think that means they're smart. And now they're hurting. Everything they had was because of oil. They still got money, but they need more money, and that's just the kind of guy Cole and me like. When the oil money was good, they put up all these office buildings, and now they're half empty. They'll give you anything to move in; first two months free, redecoration, whatever you want. They help you set up the store! I'm the roper, I go out and find them and bring them in. Cole ran the store, and he was the best.
answer: Mary Beth! As beautiful as ever. I see you brought a friend.

question: Mister Hebbing is my bodyguard, my strong right arm. Gloucester Hebbing, may I present my fine stockbroker, Henry Fellowes.
answer: Mary Beth, what we have here, uh...

question: Oh, I told Mister Hebbing all about it, how brilliant you are at making money for your special clients!
answer: Mary Beth, I hope you aren't spreading this good news too widely.

question: Well, of course not! I know how dangerous this is. But I would trust Mister Hebbing with anything. Wouldn't I, darling?
answer: Well, I'll have to take your word for it, Mary Beth. Here's your money.

question: Mister Hebbing, we are talking about breaking the law here, I want to be sure you understand that. No one gets hurt, but the law does get broken.
answer: Well, that's what the law's for, isn't it?

question: And I don't just mean the SEC. We could have the FBI breathing down our necks.
answer: I certainly hope not.

question: Loose talk is the one thing I worry about.
answer: I can keep my mouth shut, Mister Fellowes.

question: Okay, then. Sit down, sit down. The Tokyo Exchange is nine hours ahead of us, New York one hour behind. There isn't one hour of the day when both are open. Information moves, but it has to wait. Now, we have a young fellow working here -- Do you know what a hacker is, Mister Hebbing?
answer: One of those computer geniuses, isn't it?

question: You're right! And this boy tapped into that main link between Tokyo and the New York Stock Exchange. He can give us, when it's really useful, a seven second delay in that movement of information. Do you know what that means?
answer: Well, you've got your information ahead of New York, I see that.

question: Every once in a while, a major change comes through. We have seven seconds to take advantage, put our buy order, our sell order, into the computer in New York before the Tokyo data comes in.
answer: Not much time.

question: We have to be ready. We have to have the money, and we have to know what the information means, and we have to move immediately.
answer: Seven seconds. I don't see how you do it.

question: These machines -- They're in here. Want a look?
answer: Oh, Henry, no, that's just boring.

question: Come take a look. An entire-suite of main-frame computer.
answer: We're not really interested, Henry.

question: It's quite a sight. You sure?
answer: Henry, don't try Mister Hebbing's patience. He knows what machines look like.

question: Cole liked to take risks, huh?
answer: He didn't think they were risks. He was so good, Roy, he could just play with the mark.

question: And when he got serious?
answer: He'd explain he had to have cash, so there wouldn't be any paper trail for the SEC. And a lot of cash, or it wasn't worth while. The least we ever took was forty thousand, and the most was one hundred eighty-five thousand dollars! From one sucker!

question: I thought these people were broke.
answer: No, no, Roy, just cash poor. They had savings accounts, stocks to sell, houses to mortgage. Sell their wife's jewelry. Oh, they had a lot of money, when they put their minds to it. Or when I put their minds to it. I stayed with them, that's the roper's job, made them get up every penny they could raise, turn it all over to Cole.

question: And a month later, the sucker calls the cops and you're on the run.
answer: No no! He never calls the cops, not after we give him the blow-off.

question: Yeah? How?
answer: Three or four days after Cole got the money, he'd phone the sucker, tell him he'd made the move. Our buy was in the computer, we were rich, he should come collect.

question: Here you are! Two rich people!
answer: I must admit, Mister Fellowes, I had moments I was worried.

question: You brought a case? Good. What? This is a private office! Oh, my God! No! The scandal!
answer: My --? I don't I only --

question: You! You and your goddamn big mouth! Who did you tell? Who?
answer: Just one or two of the girls, just, they wouldn't --

question: Don't move! You ruined me! You destroyed me!
answer: Henry, no!

question: Get back! Get back! I'll kill the first one that follows me!
answer: Oh, Roy, it was great! We were rolling in dough, lived wherever we wanted, only pulled two or three scams a year.

question: Oh, Roy, it was great! We were rolling in dough, lived wherever we wanted, only pulled two or three scams a year.
answer: What happened to Cole?

question: He retired.
answer: Where?

question: Upstate.
answer: Upstate where?

question: Atascadero.
answer: That's where they keep the criminally insane, isn't it?

question: No, baby. Not again.
answer: It's hollow. You'll fall through.

question: Cole, it'll be all right. Honey?
answer: Can't move.

question: It's just the strain again, the stress. We'll take a vacation.
answer: It's all hollow. Nothing behind it.

question: Cole, you scare me when this happens. One of these times...
answer: Demon! Demon! That's why you can walk on it! Demon!

question: Oh, Cole, please. Please come out of it. What would I do without you? He retired, and that's it. But I didn't. I'm still the best long-con roper you'll ever see.
answer: I just bet you are, too. And now you're trying to rope me.

question: Join up with you! I watched you, Roy, I've been watching you, wondering if I should talk about this at all, or maybe just...
answer: Take a hike, you mean?

question: I need a partner, Roy. I need an inside man, and you're it. You could be as wonderful as Cole.
answer: I don't know, Myra, I never had partners. I never needed them.

question: Not to take soldiers for a hundred bucks. But how about taking a bank president for a hundred grand? Think about it. Okay?
answer: Sure.

question: See you later.
answer: I still don't see why we have to have separate rooms. You expect your father to come through?

question: Separate bathrooms, darling. I will not lay out all my cosmetics for you to knock over.
answer: Things a man isn't supposed to know.

question: You don't mind, really, do you, Roy? It's been such a wonderful evening, I guess I just wore myself out.
answer: Sure. I'm pretty tired myself. Long con. I'm the one's been conned. Who needs this? Yeah?

question: Open your door.
answer: What? What for?

question: Open it and find out. Gangway! I hope you don't mind, sir. I just washed my clothes, and I couldn't do a thing with them.
answer: You -- I don't know.

question: ) If you could have seen your face when I told you good night! You looked so, so... Ah!
answer: Oh, come here.

question: Oh, come here.
answer: Roy! What are you doing in San Diego?

question: Myra and me come down to LaJolla for the weekend.
answer: If you come out to the track, don't know me.

question: We won't hit the track. The beach. Couple a nice restaurants.
answer: What's that?

question: Four grand. For the hospital. Is that enough?
answer: Roy, I don't want money from you.

question: I pay my debts.
answer: You do?

question: Expecting visitors?
answer: No. That was the point.

question: You ought to put a bandage on that.
answer: No can do. Have to dip in and out of my bag too much. Besides, it'll heal in the air. Roy, take that back.

question: No.
answer: I thought... I was hoping we could play it straight with one another.

question: I guess not. You'll be heading east from here, huh?
answer: After the meet. Back to Baltimore.

question: Well... nice to see you again, Lilly.
answer: You, too, Roy. Prick.

question: I see him. Wait. Hold it. Just wait. Ah. Now we follow her.
answer: One of my talents. Naughty.

question: Roy! You drown in there?
answer: Be right out! You were gone for a while.

question: I went out to Delmar.
answer: ) The track? Did you run into Lilly?

question: I saw her.
answer: She didn't see you, in other words.

question: I'm not trying to make trouble, Roy. It's just, she's always so nasty to me, I thought, who is she to be so high and mighty. I saw her out there, and I called a friend of mine in Baltimore, so now I know who she is.
answer: You must have some very knowledgeable friends.

question: I'm well connected, Roy, Cole introduced me to a lot of people. Very valuable. Valuable for us.
answer: Running your broker scam, you mean.

question: You and me, Roy. What a team we'll make. We think alike; we get along together. Once or twice a year we take some slob, the rest of the time we live like this. You won't regret this, Roy.
answer: Regret what? I didn't say I was coming aboard.

question: But why not? I thought it was settled. What's holding you back?
answer: Come on, Myra, don't talk business here. This is time out.

question: You mean, it would be too tough to give me a turndown here. Easier on home grounds.
answer: Yes or no. They're both easier at home. Okay?

question: Yeah? Good! Send him in. Good to have you back, Roy. I was just looking at --
answer: Mr. Kaggs, I'm sorry.

question: You're turning me down? Makes no sense, Roy.
answer: I guess I'm just not a leader of men.

question: Oh, come on, Roy.
answer: The truth is, Mr. Kaggs --

question: Perk, remember?
answer: Okay, fine. Perk, the truth is, I like things the way they are now. Pick my own hours, have time for, uh, other activities...

question: A well-rounded life. I respect that. But it has to have a center, Roy, something you care about, something you can think about.
answer: Maybe I'm just not ready for that yet.

question: Well, Roy, if that's the way you feel, I won't badger you. Don't want to lose you as a salesman, too.
answer: Oh, I'd like to stay on. Just keep everything the way it was.

question: That's what we'll do, then. But I tell you what, Roy. Before I hire anybody else, I'll ask you one last time. Fair enough?
answer: Fair enough.

question: Darling, guess what? I had to tell you right away.
answer: And hello to you, too.

question: I called a fellow I know in Tulsa, the one who plays my chauffeur. There's a sucker there he says is made for us. And a boroker that just shut down, we can use their office, not change a thing! Now, I can scrape up ten grand without much trouble. That leaves fifteen or twenty for your end. We could start this weekend, get the sucker into position --
answer: Wait a minute! When did this happen, that we're partners?

question: What?
answer: The last I looked, we were just talking things over.

question: But the setup's there. It's there now.
answer: I don't think I need it.

question: You're too good for the small-time, Roy. Move up to where there's big dough to be made, and you don't have to stick your neck out every day.
answer: Maybe I like it where I am.

question: Well, maybe I don't! I had ten good years with Cole, and I want them back! I gotta have a partner! I looked and I looked and believe me, brother, I kissed a lot of fucking frogs, and you're my prince!
answer: Don't I get any say in this?

question: No! Because I --
answer: That's what I say.

question: What?
answer: What I say is, no. We don't do partners.

question: For Christ's sake, why not?
answer: Mostly, because you scare the shit out of me. I've seen people like you before, baby. Double-tough and sharp as they come, and you get what you want or else. But you don't make it work forever.

question: Bullshit!
answer: No; history. Sooner or later, the lightning hits. I don't want to be around when it hits you.

question: What is it? What's going on?
answer: I'm happy the way I am.

question: By God, it's your mother. It's Lilly.
answer: ) What?

question: Sure it is. That's why you act so funny around each other.
answer: What's that?

question: Don't act so goddamned innocent! You and your own mother, gah! You like to go back where you been, huh?
answer: You watch that mouth.

question: I'm wise to you, I should have seen it before, you rotten son of a bitch. How is it, huh? How do you like --
answer: How do you like this?

question: STOP!!
answer: That's not like me. I don't do violence. That's why we wouldn't work together. You're disgusting. Your mind's so filthy, it's hard even to look at you. Goodbye, Myra.

question: Lilly, I've got a couple things to think about. Well, kind of job offers, kind of. Different ways to go. I'd kind of like to talk them out, you know? Maybe just hear myself talk.
answer: Well, sure, Roy. You want me to drive up --? Okay, fine, come on down. It won't be a home-cooked meal, you know.

question: Well, that's good news. Well? Who's a boy gonna talk to, if not his mother?
answer: Roy?

question: Evening. Welcome to Phoenix.
answer: Good evening. I'd like a single for tonight.

question: Oh, everything's the same size, same price.
answer: I'm a very light sleeper, traffic noise keeps me wide awake all night.

question: Those trucks. I know exactly what you mean.
answer: Do you have something around back, facing away from the road?

question: I'll put you in one thirty-one. Very quiet. Faces the desert.
answer: Sounds perfect. I can park my car back there?

question: Right in front of the room.
answer: Fine. And I'll want to leave an early wake-up call.

question: No problem. My husband gets up the crack of dawn. It's his kidneys. Something wrong? I'm sorry. I thought you were the other lady.
answer: No. I'm me.

question: I'll give you one oh seven. That's a very nice room, very handy, in the front, right by the pool.
answer: Oh, don't you have something around back, where it's quieter?

question: Everybody wants the back tonight.
answer: I guess everybody wants privacy.

question: Roy Dillon?
answer: Yes?

question: Lieutenant Pierson, Phoenix police. I have a car here.
answer: Thank you.

question: I realize this is a shock.
answer: Well, mostly, I don't believe it.

question: That's natural.
answer: No. I mean, I don't believe it. Lilly is not a suicide. I know my mother, nothing would make her check out.

question: I'm sorry, it was her all right. Her gun, even.
answer: Gun?

question: I grant you, it's a little odd, shoot yourself with a gun with a silencer on it, but it was hers, all right. It really is your mother, Mister Dillon.
answer: It may be Lilly, but it isn't suicide.

question: Do you have any particular reason to say that?
answer: My mother... Well, I guess it doesn't matter now. She worked for gamblers. She always knew they might turn on her some day.

question: A hit, you mean. Honestly, it doesn't have that feel to it, but I'll certainly consider the possibility. Thank you for telling me.
answer: Not that it matters. This is the morgue?

question: You up to it now?
answer: Sure. Let's get it over.

question: One thing I have to caution you about. A gunshot wound...
answer: Yes, I know, I know.

question: Well, uh, you know, she ate the gun.
answer: What?

question: I'm sorry, that's an unfortunate phrase, it slipped out, I'm, to tell you the truth, Mr. Dillon, this isn't an everyday occurrence around here.
answer: Ate the gun. Oh.

question: Someone who knows her well could still identify her, that's not the problem. It's just there's, uh, it's likely to be a shock.
answer: Well, let's get the shock over with. Not many laughs in this room, eh?

question: Not many. Remove that. We'll want a full, uh, identification.
answer: Oh, Jesus.

question: No question, huh?
answer: No, its -- Why did she--?

question: That's that, then.
answer: Oh, yeah. That's that. Mom.
